conclusion: Apply principles of ideal gases and hydrostatics
Determine initial conditions for tube A and tube B
Tube A cross-sectional area is S, initial height of gas column is h1 = 24 cm
Initial volume in tube A is VA1 = h1 * S = 24S
Tube B cross-sectional area is 3S, initial height of gas column is h2 = 12 cm
Initial volume in tube B is VB1 = h2 * 3S = 36S
Initial pressure difference due to mercury level difference is Delta h = 4 cm
Initial pressure in tube B is p0 + rho * g * Delta h
Initial pressure in tube A is pA1 = p0
Initial pressure in tube B is pB1 = p0 + rho * g * Delta h
Calculate final conditions when liquid levels are equal
Common height above the bottom is h, new height for gas in tube A is hA, new height for gas in tube B is hB
Final volume in tube A is VA2 = (h1 + Delta h - h) * S = (28 - h) * S
Final volume in tube B is VB2 = (h2 + h - Delta h) * 3S = (8 + h) * 3S
Apply ideal gas law for tube A and tube B
For tube A: pA1 * VA1 / T1 = pA2 * VA2 / T2
T1 = 300 K since 27Â°C = 300 K
For tube B: pB1 * VB1 = pB2 * VB2
Pressure equilibrium condition when liquid levels are equal
Equate pressures: pA2 = pB2
Using volume relationships: pA2 = p0 * 24 / (28 - h)
Using volume relationships: pB2 = (p0 + rho * g * Delta h) * 36 / (8 + h)
